Proposed ICRA 2025 Workshop on

Generalization and Compositionality
in Robot Planning and Learning


Atlanta, USA

May 2025

Overview

The objective of the proposed workshop is to bring together researchers from parallel communities working on generalizable and compositional learning of robot skills, across diverse sequential decision-making scenarios. Recent advances in robot learning have produced powerful data-driven methods capable of learning complex skills. However, key challenges remain in developing approaches that are sample-efficient, explainable, generalizable across tasks, capable of composing primitive skills for solving longer-horizon tasks, and utilize reasoning on higher-level abstractions.

This workshop will foster research into new paradigms that integrate the strengths of data-driven deep learning and structured symbolic reasoning to create more sample-efficient, generalizable, interpretable, and compositional robot learning. Key topics include explainable representation learning, causal reasoning for transferability, inverse reinforcement learning, neuro-symbolic architectures, curriculum learning for compositionality, and human-in-the-loop modeling.

While significant progress has been made in ML, AI planning, and robotics, achieving true generalization and compositionality in robot learning systems remains an open challenge. As robots are tasked with operating in increasingly open-ended environments and tackling diverse tasks, the ability to generalize learned skills across situations and compose them in novel ways becomes crucial. We aim to bring together researchers from multiple fields like ML, AI Planning, Robotics, Control Theory, etc. to systematically discuss the key challenges, approaches, and future directions towards enabling generalizable and compositional robot learning. By fostering interdisciplinary collaboration and knowledge sharing, we can work towards developing more robust robot systems capable of leveraging their learned skills in a generalizable and compositional manner to meet the complexities of real-world applications.

By bridging communities across imitation learning, deep RL, hierarchical RL, AI planning, interpretable AI and control, the workshop aims to lay the foundations for a new generation of transparent, data-efficient, symbolic reasoning, and adaptable robot skill-learning agents. The goal is to foster the development of robots that can acquire generalizable skills from sparse data, provide explanations for their behavior, and continually extend their capabilities and achieve long-horizon goals by composition of their learned skills.

We welcome submissions including, but not limited to, the following topics:

  • Multi-task and goal-conditioned policy learning (image, language, etc.).
  • Learning for task and motion planning.
  • Use of foundational models (LLMs and VLMs) for skill decomposition and composition.
  • Options discovery; Skill recognition; Segmenting/sequencing demonstrations.
  • Distilling generalizable knowledge from demonstrations.
  • Hierarchical reinforcement learning for robots.
  • Distilling generalizable knowledge from demonstrations.
  • Safe reinforcement learning for robots.
  • Learning general robotic task specifications.
  • Learning representations for adaptive, interpretable, explainable, and reusable skills.
  • Learning and synthesis of generalizable solutions for robotics.
  • Learning high-level models and hierarchical solutions for robot learning and planning.
  • Cross-domain skill transfer and generalization (e.g. Sim2Real).
